title: Sorry, Todd Phillips – woke culture isn’t the reason you’re not funny anymore
text:
Todd, pictured with Joaquin Phoenix, thinks comedy is dead (Picture: Joel C Ryan/Invision/AP)

2019 has given us some of the biggest and boldest comedy hits of recent years. Fleabag cleaned up at the Emmys, Booksmart had us all in stitches, and I Think You Should Leave has shown how you do sketch comedy.

But it turns out we’re all wrong for laughing, because according to Todd Phillips, comedy is dead.

Phillips is currently riding high on a wave of success and controversy for directing Joker, a comic book drama that is equally receiving praise for its grittiness and Joaquin Phoenix’s performance, and criticism for proposed links to real life violence and incels.

Before Phillips took on DC’s most iconic villain, he was best known for his work in comedy, having directed and written Road Trip, Old School, Starksy and Hutch, the two The Hangover sequels, and having directed and produced the Golden Globe winning original.

Advertisement

And it turns out he left comedy because we’re all too gosh darn sensitive and politically correct.

Speaking to Vanity Fair, he said: ‘Go try to be funny nowadays with this woke culture. There were articles written about why comedies don’t work anymore—I’ll tell you why, because all the f***ing funny guys are like, “F*** this s***, because I don’t want to offend you.”

Phoebe Waller-Bridge would disagree (Picture: Christopher Polk/Variety/REX)

‘It’s hard to argue with 30million people on Twitter. You just can’t do it, right? So you just go, “I’m out.”’

At this point in the interview, I rolled my eyes so hard that I briefly viewed life from the back of my head. I can’t stand people getting their knickers in a twist over so-called woke/PC culture at the best of times – oh wow, you can’t use racist slurs anymore, I’m so sorry – but Todd’s comments are even more infuriating because they’re just not true.

Comedy is absolutely thriving, and yes, edgy comedy is included in this. The aforementioned Emmy award winning, critically acclaimed Fleabag opens series one with Phoebe Waller-Bridge’s character engaging in anal sex with a well-endowed man and proceeding to question the size of her anus.

The hysterical I Think You Should Leave pushes the boundaries of sketch comedy in 16 minute bites. A Girls Trip sequel is planned after the original – a film where Tiffany Haddish’s character pees all over a crowd, drugs her mates and acts out the oral sex act ‘grapefruiting’ on a banana – made $140million.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Sure, Girls Trip was an exception to the rule, as comedies aren’t the box office hits they used to be (The Hangover had a worldwide gross of $467 million). But that’s not because people are too ‘woke’ to go see them anymore.

Comedies just aren’t the draw anymore, with production companies preferring to plough their money into comic book movies, which are the trend du jour and will bring in billions. Trends are cyclical, and at the moment, studios just aren’t willing to spend big budgets on comedies.

Girls Trip wasn’t exactly squeaky clean (Picture: Michele K Short/Universal/Kobal/REX/Shutterstock)

But that doesn’t mean it isn’t making money elsewhere. Netflix is splashing out on comedy specials from some of the biggest and most bankable stand-ups on the circuit – and yes, they’re being ‘edgy’.

If you like your comedy un-PC, you have Dave Chapelle in Sticks and Stones making jokes about child abuse and not believing Michael Jackson’s accusers. Un-woke comedy is alive and well, folks, so saying people are too sensitive for it to be produced is a lie.

The actual issue is that this kind of comedy is now being criticised, and the real sensitive people are those who can’t handle having their work critiqued.

Todd Phillips’ last comedy was The Hangover Part III, which has a rating of 20 per cent on Rotten Tomatoes. It didn’t receive that rating because PC, woke lefties made it that Todd couldn’t make edgy jokes anymore. It just wasn’t that good.

Advertisement

Blaming the climate for your movie sucking makes you the sensitive one, Todd. And, side note, The Hangover – the actually brilliant one of the trilogy – was the only film not to have been written by Phillips. Take from that what you will.

Millennials still like comedy, in all forms. We laugh at memes all day, for god’s sake. We’re just not that into marginalised communities being made the butt of the joke, when their existence already sees them attacked on a daily basis.

For me, somebody making a joke about the trans community or minorities isn’t funny because it’s just lazy. It’s very easy to make a joke about a vulnerable target. It doesn’t make you risky, anybody can do it, and no, your rights aren’t being taken away to say them.

Shane Gillis was back on stage making jokes about Asians days after being fired from SNL. Louis CK is still touring and mocking Parkland survivors.

Don’t get me wrong, I think you can make jokes about uncomfortable topics. Take the Scottish comedian Daniel Sloss. On his current tour, X, there is a large section about sexual assault, while on his Netflix special, DARK, he discusses the death of his sister. And I have watched both and belly laughed. That’s because the victims are never the punchline. That takes a good comedian.

Advertisement

Anybody can use a slur, or slag off trans people, or put on a racist accent. It’s not that hard, and it doesn’t make you revolutionary. To be a clever comedian, you have to aim a bit higher than that – and you can’t just blame the ‘woke’ because you’re not funny anymore.
